title: Bloodthirsty
data:
**Bloodthirsty** is a [property](/wiki/Property "Property") that appears in *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")* and occurs with weapons - a bloodthirsty weapon [wielded](/wiki/Wielded "Wielded") by a [hero](/wiki/Hero "Hero") attacks peaceful and hostile [monsters](/wiki/Monster "Monster") indiscriminately when moving towards them.

[ ]

## Contents

- [1 Description](#Description)

- [2 Strategy](#Strategy)

- [3 Messages](#Messages)

- [4 Variants](#Variants)

  - [4.1 SLASH'EM](#SLASH.27EM)
    - [4.1.1 Messages](#Messages_2)
  - [4.2 dNetHack](#dNetHack)

- [5 References](#References)

## Description

Bloodthirstiness is solely associated with the [artifact weapon](/wiki/Artifact_weapon "Artifact weapon") [Stormbringer](/wiki/Stormbringer "Stormbringer"), and is not formally defined with a singular flag in [artilist.h](/wiki/Artilist.h "Artilist.h") - it is instead handled in [mhitu.c](/wiki/Mhitu.c "Mhitu.c") code that pertains specifically to Stormbringer.

While the hero wields a bloodthirsty weapon, attempting to move into a monster's space will attack the monster with that weapon, regardless of whether or not it is peaceful, tame or hostile. This prevents the hero from displacing pets and skips the confirmation prompt that normally comes up when a hero would attack in the direction of a non-hostile monster, thus automatically angering peaceful monsters and abusing tame ones.[\[1\]](#cite_note-1)[\[2\]](#cite_note-2)

[Travel](/wiki/Travel "Travel") using the [\_](/wiki/Underscore "Underscore") key while wielding a bloodthirsty weapon will also cause a hero to attack pets instead of automatically swapping places with them, if they get in the hero's path.[\[3\]](#cite_note-3)

*The following information pertains to an upcoming version ([3.7.0](/wiki/3.7.0 "3.7.0")). If this version is now released, please verify that it is still accurate, then update the page to incorporate this information.*

Wielding a bloodthirsty weapon while traveling will also attack peaceful monsters in addition to pets.

## Strategy

Unwielding Stormbringer when not in combat is recommended, as its tendency to attack non-hostile targets limits your tactical options.

## Messages

- Your bloodthirsty blade attacks!

  Stormbringer caused you to automatically attack a non-hostile monster.

## Variants

Variants of *NetHack* may add other artifact weapons with bloodthirsty properties and/or alter how it functions.

### SLASH'EM

In [SLASH'EM](/wiki/SLASH%27EM "SLASH'EM"), it is possible to two-weapon two artifacts, and wielding Stormbringer in the offhand this way will cause the hero to automatically attack monsters as if it were wielded. This also applies to [SlashTHEM](/wiki/SlashTHEM "SlashTHEM").

#### Messages

- The black blade will not be thwarted!

  Stormbringer caused you to attack a non-hostile monster while in the offhand.

### dNetHack

In [dNetHack](/wiki/DNetHack "DNetHack"), [notdNetHack](/wiki/NotdNetHack "NotdNetHack") and [notnotdNetHack](/wiki/NotnotdNetHack "NotnotdNetHack"), there are additional bloodthirsty artifact weapons, and all of them use the flag `ARTI_BLOODTHRST` in artilist.h:

- [Slave to Armok](/wiki/DNetHack_artifacts#Slave_to_Armok "DNetHack artifacts")
- [Genocide](/wiki/DNetHack_artifacts#Genocide "DNetHack artifacts")
- [The Wand of Orcus](/wiki/The_Wand_of_Orcus_\(dNetHack\) "The Wand of Orcus (dNetHack)")
- [The Tsurugi of Muramasa](/wiki/The_Tsurugi_of_Muramasa "The Tsurugi of Muramasa")

Furthermore, the bloodthirsty property functions completely differently in these variants. Instead of only attacking on careless movement, bloodthirsty weapons in dNetHack lash out at monsters around the hero passively: Every turn, the weapon will attempt to attack each adjacent monster, with a 1⁄4 chance per monster. For peaceful monsters, a second check is made to avoid including it as a target, with this chance scaling inversely with the hero's [sanity](/wiki/Sanity "Sanity"). The sanity-based chance functions identically to permanent [madnesses](/wiki/Madness "Madness"), so it becomes exponentially more likely with lower sanity and becomes exceedingly rare at high sanity.

Regardless of sanity or the number of adjacent monsters, at most one extra bloodthirsty attack will be made per turn. However, because each target is rolled separately, more adjacent monsters will increase the chance of an attack occurring. This makes bloodthirstiness a double-edged sword: it can grant extra attacks versus hostile monsters, but may also forcibly attack peaceful and tame monsters unless the hero unwields the weapon. [Clear thoughts](/wiki/Clear_thoughts "Clear thoughts") can prevent bloodthirsty attacks against peaceful and tame monsters.

## References

1. [↑](#cite_ref-1) [src/uhitm.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 30](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/uhitm.c#L30)
2. [↑](#cite_ref-2) [src/uhitm.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 474](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/uhitm.c#L474)
3. [↑](#cite_ref-3) [src/hack.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 1566](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/hack.c#L1566): *The code attempts to "attack" monsters that can be displaced in order to swap places with them, but "It's fine to displace pets" is false when wielding a bloodthirsty weapon.*
